"Women are born with pain built in": Fleabag's Love Letter to Modern Feminism

11/10/2021

Camila Hernandez analyses the inexorable relationship between Phoebe Waller-Bridge's meta-comedy and current feminist discourse.

Image by BBC

By Kyle Boulton

Who is Fleabag? She answers this herself: â€œIâ€™m a greedy, perverted, selfish, apathetic, cynical, depraved, morally bankrupt woman who can't even call herself a feminist.â€

Throughout the show, Fleabag proves these traits several times over â€” yet her poise, charm and dark wit make her an utterly compelling protagonist. Though her decisions are, more often than not, poor and uncalculated, Fleabag doesnâ€™t force us to feel any sort of way. Despite the cleverly cut-off jokes and Waller-Bridgeâ€™s signature contorted face of amused disgust (you know the one), thereâ€™s an alluring yet twisted autonomy that our â€˜narratorâ€™ possesses. At the core of her character is the unrelenting expression of the ribald, aggressive and independent behaviour that women, in real life and in television, are discouraged to display. In fact, Fleabag is not a â€˜difficultâ€™ woman after all â€” she is just real.

Although fans come to the show time and time again for the funny antics and quick-witted asides, the untethered intimacy between Fleabag and the camera (and also men) is what makes her seem like a redeemable character. Working as both a comic relief and as an intimate confessional, it seems like the perfect, self-aware technique. And though these devices have long been gathering the dust of cliche and donâ€™t seem that effective on paper, Waller-Bridge somehow finds a new way to make them flourish on screen.

Breaking-the-fourth-wall is a trope that has been used primarily as an extension of a screenwriterâ€™s limited male perspective. Think of film and TVâ€™s famous examples of to-camera asides: Ferris Bueller, Annie Hallâ€™s Alvy Singer, American Psychoâ€™s Patrick Bateman, House of Cardsâ€™ Frank Underwood. Of course, there have been some female-driven narratives carried out through the agency of a main character voice, such as in Clarissa Explains It All and Sex and the City, but in these their dialogues read like a hollowed-out email from a female colleague.

However, Waller-Bridge doesnâ€™t stop here in her revolutionary journey to deface every detail of conventional television from their macho origins. Fleabag, and we are not eased into this at all, has a considerable sexual appetite. Writing for The New Yorker, Nussbaum adds that â€œ her libido feels punishingly theatricalâ€”sheâ€™s addicted to the â€œdramaâ€ of sex, its awkwardness and cruelty, detumescing intimacy whenever it emerges from the bedsheets.â€ This is another clear way in which Waller-Bridge pits femininity against its own system, a system that our protagonist is always trying to game. â€œI want someone to tell me what to believe in, who to vote for, who to love and how to tell them.â€ Fleabag remarks snarkily at one moment. As well as more satirical statements like this one: â€œIf you rid a woman of her head and limbs you canâ€™t really expect her to do anything other than roll around.â€

Waller-Bridgeâ€™s desire to challenge our relationship with Fleabag is evident in the second series, which shifts beyond raised eyebrows, smirks and exposition. The fourth wall device is still an important part of the narrative structure, but its role expands beyond an extended conversation between character and audience. We are no longer her only source of salvation. She leaves the camera resting on the frame of a bus-stop, and we are left feeling unwanted, unneeded. We have served our purpose.

In a conversation on BBC Radio 4 Womanâ€™s Hour, Waller-Bridge detailed Fleabagâ€™s â€˜vulnerableâ€™ relationship with feminism: â€œShe doesnâ€™t understand the rules of it.â€ she says. Yet, â€œshe knows in her bones that itâ€™s the thing she wants to be and she wants to identify as a feminist but she feels like sheâ€™s letting feminism down all the time.â€ The screenwriter herself stated that even she feels â€œslightly frightened by the nuances [of feminism] and that there are traps out there.â€

Despite this undercurrent of anxiety surrounding feminism, there is nevertheless a hopeful potential to the â€˜bad feminismâ€™ Fleabag half-jokingly subscribes to, portrayed in both her and Waller-Bridgeâ€™s belief systems. For what appears to be a quintessential â€˜bad feminismâ€™ in the first season slowly reveals itself, in the second, to also be a mesh with a kind of humanism. In this shift, Fleabag brilliantly bridges the two, conjuring up humanistic questions of meaning and existence while also revealing humanismâ€™s limits, forever distorting it with the â€˜badnessâ€™ of feminism. Such a hilariously flawed and outrageously female character as Fleabag herself may be, these two important components are what make her the perfect imperfect human for voicing the struggles of what it means to forgive ourselves for self-destructive tendencies.

But what makes the rest of us, with our socially-mediated outward glances, so different from her? Everyone else in Fleabagâ€™s life is pretending as hard as she is, after all, just without an audience to talk to. We can never tell what anyone is really thinking, and we will never really know who â€˜weâ€™ are to Fleabag. Perhaps it is when she stops talking to us that she stops dissociating, becomes less isolated from herself, steps out of the frame of our gaze, and into her own.
